article.simpara: The AsciiDoc distribution includes a source filter for highlighting code syntax.

section.title: DocBook Outputs
section.simpara: AsciiDoc encloses the source code in a DocBook programlisting element and leaves source code highlighting to the DocBook toolchain (dblatex has a particularly nice programlisting highlighter). The DocBook programlisting element is assigned two attributes:

listitem.simpara: The language attribute is set to the AsciiDoc language attribute.
The linenumbering attribute is set to the AsciiDoc src_numbered attribute (numbered or unnumbered).

section.title: HTML Outputs
section.simpara: You have the choice of three HTML source code highlighters, your selection is determined by the source-highlighter attribute (defaults to source-highlight):

note.simpara: Set the source-highlighter attribute from the asciidoc(1) command-line or in the document header (not in the document body, because the configuration file conditional macros are processed at load time).

section.title: GNU Source Highlight
section.simpara: The default highlighter is the GNU source-highlight which can highlight html4, html5 and xhtml11 outputs. The GNU source-highlight must be installed and the source-highlight command must reside in the shell search PATH.

section.title: Highlight
section.simpara: You can use Highlight syntax highlighter for xhtml11, html5 and html4 outputs (set the source-highlighter attribute to highlighter).

listitem.simpara: The highlight command must reside in the shell search PATH.

The AsciiDoc encoding attribute is passed to Highlighter using the --encoding command-line option.

section.title: Pygments
section.simpara: The Pygments syntax highlighter can be used for xhtml11 and html5 outputs (set the source-highlighter attribute to pygments).

listitem.simpara: The pygmentize command must reside in the shell search PATH.

The AsciiDoc encoding attribute is passed to Pygments using the -O command-line option.

section.title: Block attributes
section.simpara: The following attributes can be included in source code block attribute lists.

listitem.simpara: style, language and src_numbered are the first three positional attributes in that order.
The args attribute allows the inclusion of arbitrary (highlighter dependent) command options.

note.simpara: The language names vary between highlighters — consult the selected highlighter manual.

listitem.simpara: Set to numbered to include line numbers.
Include this attribute value in the highlighter command-line (HTML outputs) or in the programlisting element (DocBook).

section.title: Source code paragraphs
section.simpara: The source paragraph style will highlight a paragraph of source code. These three code paragraphs:
section.screen:
[source,python] if n < 0: print 'Hello World!'
:language: python
[source] if n < 0: print 'Hello World!'
[source,ruby,numbered] [true, false].cycle([0, 1, 2, 3, 4]) do |a, b| puts "#{a.inspect} => #{b.inspect}"

section.title: Unnumbered source code listing
section.screen: [source,python] --------------------------------------------------------------------- ''' A multi-line comment.''' def sub_word(mo): ''' Single line comment.''' word = mo.group('word') # Inline comment if word in keywords[language]: return quote + word + quote else: return word ---------------------------------------------------------------------

section.title: Numbered source code listing with callouts
section.screen:
[source,ruby,numbered] --------------------------------------------------------------------- # # Useful Ruby base class extensions. #
class Array
# Execute a block passing it corresponding items in # +self+ and +other_array+. # If self has less items than other_array it is repeated.
def cycle(other_array) # :yields: item, other_item other_array.each_with_index do |item, index| yield(self[index % self.length], item) end end
end
if $0 == __FILE__ # <1> # Array#cycle test # true => 0 # false => 1 # true => 2 # false => 3 # true => 4 puts 'Array#cycle test' # <2> [true, false].cycle([0, 1, 2, 3, 4]) do |a, b| puts "#{a.inspect} => #{b.inspect}" end end ---------------------------------------------------------------------
<1> First callout. <2> Second callout.
section.programlisting:
# # Useful Ruby base class extensions. #
class Array
# Execute a block passing it corresponding items in # +self+ and +other_array+. # If self has less items than other_array it is repeated.
def cycle(other_array) # :yields: item, other_item other_array.each_with_index do |item, index| yield(self[index % self.length], item) end end
end
if $0 == __FILE__ # # Array#cycle test # true => 0 # false => 1 # true => 2 # false => 3 # true => 4 puts 'Array#cycle test' # [true, false].cycle([0, 1, 2, 3, 4]) do |a, b| puts "#{a.inspect} => #{b.inspect}" end end

listitem.simpara: If the source language attribute has been set (using an AttributeEntry or from the command-line) you don’t have to specify it in each source code block.
You should place callout markers inside source code comments to ensure they are not misinterpreted and mangled by the highlighter.
